awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC:  Water and Environmental Technology Center
awd_abstract_narration:
In Phase II operation, the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC intends to minimize any adverse effects of emerging contaminants (EC) on human health and/or the environment. The research challenges in this area include the need for more scientific information about levels, fate, transport, ecological and health impacts of ECs in the environment, the need for improved detection and monitoring capabilities, and for new cost-effective treatment technologies and optimization of existing operations at both water and wastewater treatment plants.  Center engineers and environmental scientists utilizing microbial, chemical, and mathematic approaches will work collaboratively in coordination with center industry representatives to perform this research.  WET's industrial, need-focused research program aims to enhance scientific understanding and help address potentially significant health and environmental problems.

The challenges addressed and potential benefits derived from the work of the Water and Environmental Technology (WET) I/UCRC impact several industries including: the Pharmaceutical and Personal Care Products Industries; the Oil and Natural Gas Industry; Pesticide and other Chemicals Industry; entities that treat wastewater and drinking water; and companies that create and service technologies for the removal of contaminants from water.  Students and faculty will experience state of the art research projects of value to both industry and the community. Many member companies have overseas installations, and students will be exposed to regulatory, technological, social and cultural aspects of different countries, enhancing their global experiences. In addition, every effort will be made to engage and involve minority students, as well as students and teachers from local K-12 schools, in part through existing programs at the center's institutions.  The Center will further enhance the ongoing efforts at the three institutions of integrating research into classroom teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The Water and Environmental Technology (WET) center at Arizona State University (ASU) goal is to advance the science of water through the promotion of scientific research ensuring the quality of water. This is achieved through partnerships and the pooling of the resources by the university and industry. The WET center develops and tests technologies to understand and mitigate emerging and traditional contaminants in water. The center’s mission is to develop methods and technologies to detect, understand, mitigate and/or control contaminants including conventional and emerging contaminants of concern, that can adversely impact water quality and the environment.

The WET center focuses on water contaminants (microbial, chemical, physical), water quality, and water treatment technologies, researching conventional and emerging contaminants of concern (ECCs). ECCs generally refers to chemicals, biological agents, and materials recently detected in the environment that may pose a potential or real threat to human health and the environment, but that are not generally regulated or expected to undergo changes in regulations. ECCs include microbial pathogens (viruses, bacteria and parasites) micropollutants, chemical compounds of emerging concern (pharmaceuticals), microconstituents (microplastics, and others). The WET center's engineers and scientists employ molecular, microbial, chemical, and mathematical approaches to perform collaborative research. Faculty and students work with industry representatives and build upon their research dealing with water contaminants and technologies.

The center continues to recruit students and transform them into a diverse cadre of professional scientists and engineers who will spearhead the future growth and developments in technological innovation that enable access to clean water everywhere in the world. To address this critical challenge, we continue to build on the existing STEM programs at ASU by strengthening the multi-disciplinary aspect of this educational program. The program allows students to be involved at various levels of innovation via design development, prototype evaluation, strategies for creative problem-solving and generating solutions for communities. Such a comprehensive program will realize a new generation of dedicated professionals vital for providing access to clean water in the US and abroad. Our strategy has been proven successful in capturing the interests and enthusiasm of a diverse group of young engineer/scientists, in giving them a first-hand opportunity to see the tremendous impact that their solutions can have on the wellness of their communities and the society.

Intellectual Merit: Many articles have been published that advance the current knowledge of drinking water treatment processes, microbial detection and occurrence, survival and disinfection, and microbial indicator and pathogen transport, for example, Legionella survival and transport in water environments. The research projects and outreach program provide a platform for mentoring undergraduate, M.S. and Ph.D. students, by providing them hands-on research experience under the Center’s activities.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the WET center have clearly benefited society and industry in multiple ways. First, providing a technological plan to provide safe, sustainable water to society is the number one priority. Such a plan will ensure the maintenance of optimum human and environmental health.

In addition to this priority, there are additional beneficial broader impacts summarized as the following.

  • Research within the center has added to the base of technologies for water analysis and treatment, reducing the cost of public utilities to the community, and to the manufacturing industry and government for their waste management.
  • Education has also benefited.
    • Training and graduation of multiple MS and Ph.D. graduate students
    • Internships with the private and public sectors for undergraduate and graduate students
    • New hires within the private and public sectors from a pool of graduating students
  • Outreach activities have included peer review publications, state, national and international presentations
  • Diversity. The center has focused efforts to attract minorities and underrepresented groups into center activities.
